aiCapability.label: AI Capability
aiCapability.tooltip: Overall power of AI systems. Higher values accelerate automation of tech roles and increase wage gains for AI-complementary positions.
aiCapability.simpleTooltip: How capable AI is at doing tech jobs — from basic tools to full automation.

adoptionSpeed.label: Adoption Speed
adoptionSpeed.simpleLabel: How fast are companies adopting AI?
adoptionSpeed.tooltip: How quickly tech companies deploy AI tools. Drives effective automation rate alongside AI capability.
adoptionSpeed.simpleTooltip: How quickly tech companies are actually rolling out AI tools in their workflows.

regulation.label: Regulation
regulation.tooltip: Government AI regulation stringency. Slows adoption and reduces tech job displacement.
regulation.simpleTooltip: How aggressively the government regulates AI — slowing its rollout and protecting workers.

retraining.label: Retraining Programs
retraining.simpleLabel: How much job retraining is available?
retraining.tooltip: Investment in worker upskilling. Reduces job loss rate and raises the employment floor — tech workers who retrain find new roles rather than staying unemployed.
retraining.simpleTooltip: How much investment goes into helping displaced workers learn new skills and find new jobs.

transfers.label: Social Transfers
transfers.tooltip: Government transfer payments (UBI-style). Compresses inequality, funds retraining pipelines for displaced tech workers (reduces the stability hit from layoff waves, not the layoffs themselves), and stabilizes household spending.
transfers.simpleTooltip: Government payments (like UBI) to workers who lost their jobs — keeping them afloat while they transition.

laborProtection.label: Labor Protections
laborProtection.tooltip: Strength of labor laws against layoffs. Reduces per-year job loss rate in the tech sector.
laborProtection.simpleTooltip: How hard it is for companies to lay off tech workers — legal protections, severance requirements, etc.

corporateConcentration.label: Corporate Concentration
corporateConcentration.simpleLabel: How much do big tech firms dominate?
corporateConcentration.tooltip: Market power of large tech firms. Suppresses wage growth and increases inequality as fewer companies capture more of the AI productivity gains.
corporateConcentration.simpleTooltip: Whether a few giant companies control most of tech — which concentrates AI gains at the top.

openSourceAccess.label: Open Source AI Access
openSourceAccess.tooltip: Availability of open-source AI models. Positive = widely available (lowers barrier to automation, accelerates displacement of mid-tier tech roles). Negative = restricted/proprietary only (slows displacement but concentrates AI power among large firms).
openSourceAccess.simpleTooltip: Whether AI is locked behind big companies or freely available to anyone — which affects who gets disrupted and how fast.

talentPipelineStrength.label: Talent Pipeline Strength
talentPipelineStrength.simpleLabel: How strong is the tech talent pipeline?
talentPipelineStrength.tooltip: Robustness of tech talent supply (universities, bootcamps, retraining programs). Higher values dampen tech layoff spirals when infrastructure roles are displaced — new talent absorbs the gaps faster.
talentPipelineStrength.simpleTooltip: How many new skilled tech workers are entering the workforce through schools, bootcamps, and training programs.
